questions.text: A 16-year-old patient happens to have pellagra-like eruptions on skin in spring season from the last 5 years with normal HIAA and high aminoaciduria. Indole levels in urine are normal. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hartnup disease

 

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a defect in the absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids in the intestine and renal tubules. This defect leads to increased excretion of amino acids in the urine, known as aminoaciduria. Tryptophan is a precursor for niacin (Vitamin B3) synthesis, and its deficiency can lead to pellagra-like symptoms, including dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, often referred to as the "3 D's" of pellagra.

 

In this case, the patient presents with pellagra-like eruptions and high aminoaciduria. The normal HIAA levels rule out a carcinoid tumor, which would show elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine due to increased serotonin production. The absence of dietary history indicative of niacin or tryptophan deficiency (as seen in nutritional pellagra) further supports Hartnup disease as the diagnosis. Additionally, essential fructosuria is a benign condition and does not cause skin eruptions or pellagra-like symptoms.

 

Note –

 

  • Tryptophan is an aromatic amino acid with a bulky indole ring side chain.
  • 60 mg of tryptophan converts into 1 mg of niacin
  • Best Treatment of Niacin deficiency - Niacin or nicotinamide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid tumor: Carcinoid syndrome would typically present with elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine due to excessive conversion of tryptophan to serotonin. The normal HIAA levels in this patient make carcinoid tumor an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option B. Nutritional pellagra: This condition is due to a dietary deficiency of niacin (Vitamin B3) or its precursor tryptophan. However, the patient does not present with a history of dietary deficiency, and the high aminoaciduria suggests an alternative diagnosis.

 

Option D. Essential fructosuria: This condition is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme fructokinase, leading to fructose excretion in urine. However, it is asymptomatic and does not cause skin eruptions or any pellagra-like symptoms, making it an incorrect answer in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra or pellagra like symptoms can result from (Differential Diagnosis):

 

  • Niacin (B3) deficiency due to a diet high in maize, which is low in tryptophan.
  • Vitamin B6 deficiency, since the enzyme kynureninase, which catalyzes a step in niacin synthesis from tryptophan, requires B6 as a cofactor. B6 deficiency also leads to increased synthesis of xanthurenic acid
  • Carcinoid syndrome: can be differentiated with elevated HIAA level with pellagra like symptoms.
  • Hartnup disease can present with pellagra-like symptoms due to defective absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids, leading to high aminoaciduria and niacin deficiency.

questions.text: All of the following are boundaries of the quadrangular space, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. A) Supraspinatus

 

Explanation:

 

 

The quadrangular space is an important anatomical landmark in the scapular region where the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral vessels pass. The correct boundaries of this space include teres minor superiorly (forming the superior boundary), teres major inferiorly (forming the inferior boundary), long head of triceps medially (forming the medial boundary), and the surgical neck of humerus laterally. Supraspinatus is not a boundary of this space - it lies in the supraspinous fossa of the scapula, superior to the region of the quadrangular space.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Teres minor: This is actually a correct boundary of the quadrangular space, forming its superior border. It is one of the rotator cuff muscles originating from the lateral border of the scapula.
  • Option C. Teres major: This is a correct boundary of the quadrangular space, forming its inferior border. It originates from the dorsal surface of the inferior angle of the scapula.
  • Option D. Long head of triceps: This is a correct boundary of the quadrangular space, forming its medial border. It originates from the infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The quadrangular space is bounded by teres minor superiorly, teres major inferiorly, long head of triceps medially, and the surgical neck of humerus laterally - with the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral vessels as its contents.

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by the presence of mica-like adherent scales? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pityriasis lichenoides chronica

 

  • Pityriasis lichenoides chronica (PLC) is specifically characterized by mica-like adherent scales. 
  • This chronic papulosquamous condition presents with polymorphic eruptions of successive crops of asymptomatic red-brown papules, which are surmounted by a central, adherent mica-like scale. 

 

 

  • These scales have a distinctive shiny, flaky appearance resembling mica mineral. 

 

 

 

  • The lesions of PLC heal with hypopigmentation and commonly affect the trunk and proximal parts of the extremities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis features silvery white, loose, lamellar scales rather than mica-like adherent scales. 

 

 

  • These scales are easily removable and when scraped, demonstrate the Auspitz sign (pinpoint bleeding spots). 
  • Psoriatic scales are described as micaceous, silvery white, but they are not adherent like those in PLC.

 

Option B. Pityriasis rosea:

 

  • Pityriasis rosea is characterized by a collarette of scales on the leading edge of lesions, not mica-like adherent scales. 
  • The scales in pityriasis rosea have their outer edge attached within the active margin of the lesion, while the inner edge remains free (which produces the "hanging curtain sign" when stretched).

 

Option C. Seborrheic dermatitis: 

 

  • Seborrheic dermatitis features greasy or yellowish scales rather than mica-like adherent scales. 

 

 

  • These scales are typically found in sebum-rich areas of the body, such as the scalp, face, and flexures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pityriasis lichenoides chronica is distinguished by its mica-like adherent scales surmounting red-brown papules, which heal with characteristic hypopigmentation — a key diagnostic feature that differentiates it from other papulosquamous disorders.

questions.text: What blood group can be transfused to an individual with Bombay blood group? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oh

 

The Bombay blood group, also known as the Oh blood group, is a rare blood type that lacks the H antigen, which is present in all other blood types. Individuals with the Bombay blood group have antibodies against the H antigen, which means they cannot receive blood from any of the common ABO blood groups, including the universal donor O blood group, as it contains the H antigen. Transfusing blood that contains the H antigen to someone with the Bombay blood group would lead to a severe hemolytic reaction. Therefore, individuals with the Bombay blood group can only receive blood from other Bombay blood group donors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AB negative: This blood group contains the H antigen and would cause a hemolytic reaction in a Bombay blood group individual.

 

Option B. B: This blood group also contains the H antigen, making it incompatible with the Bombay blood group.

 

Option D. O negative: Although O negative is considered a universal donor in the context of the ABO and Rh systems, it still contains the H antigen and is therefore not compatible with the Bombay blood group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Individuals with the Bombay blood group (Oh) can only receive blood from other Bombay blood group donors due to the presence of anti-H antibodies.

questions.text: The General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) primarily describes the body's response to which of the following? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Stressful situations

 

Explanation: 

 

The General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) is a model developed by Hans Selye that describes the body's physiological response to stress. It outlines how the body responds to any demand (stressor) placed upon it, regardless of whether the stressor is physical, psychological, or environmental. The GAS consists of three stages: alarm reaction (fight-or-flight response), resistance (adaptation), and exhaustion. It represents a general biological response to stress rather than being specific to any particular psychiatric condition.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Panic Attacks (Incorrect): While panic attacks involve physiological stress responses, they represent a specific type of anxiety response rather than the general stress response described by GAS. Panic attacks are acute episodes characterized by intense fear and specific physical symptoms like palpitations, sweating, and shortness of breath.
  • Option B. Depression (Incorrect): Depression represents a mood disorder with persistent low mood, anhedonia, and other emotional and physical symptoms. While chronic stress can contribute to depression, and there may be HPA axis dysregulation in depression, GAS describes the general stress response rather than the specific pathophysiology of depression.
  • Option C. Anxiety Disorders (Incorrect): Anxiety disorders involve excessive worry, fear, and physiological arousal. While anxiety certainly involves stress response systems, GAS describes the broader physiological response to any stressor, not just anxiety disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) is a fundamental model describing how the body responds physiologically to any type of stressor through three stages: alarm reaction, resistance, and exhaustion. It involves the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis and represents a non-specific response to stress rather than being particular to any specific psychiatric condition.

choices.text: Bar and boot plaster

questions.text: An 80-year-old patient suffers with Intracapsular femoral neck fracture. What would be the most appropriate management option for her management?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemiarthroplasty

 

INTRACAPSULAR FEMORAL NECK FRACTURE

 

  • Intracapsular femoral neck fractures (FNFs) account for approximately 50% of all hip fractures.
  • Intracapsular fractures demonstrate limited healing potential due to the absence of the periosteal layer, so the fracture is only immersed in the surrounding synovial fluid. 
  • These injuries occur secondary to low-energy falls in older individuals and higher-energy traumatic mechanisms in younger patients. 
  • However, most of these fractures occur in older people with underlying osteoporosis.
  • Displaced intracapsular femoral neck fractures in older people are typically managed with hip reconstruction procedures – the femoral head and neck are replaced with a reconstruction prosthesis.
  • These procedures include hip hemiarthroplasty or total hip arthroplasty (THA).
  • Non-displaced fractures may be managed with fixation using cannulated screw fixation.
  • Hemiarthroplasty, or femoral head replacement, is recommended for displaced intracapsular FNFs, especially in older patients with low activity levels.
  • THA is preferred for patients with intact ambulatory function or evidence of hip pain and degenerative arthritis.
  • Girdlestone resection arthroplasty (GRA) may be an option for patients who are unsuitable for hemiarthroplasty due to conditions like systemic infections or severe neurological impairment.
  • Hemiarthroplasty and THA are contraindicated in patients with an active hip infection.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Russell’s traction: This is a non-surgical method used for younger patients with femoral neck fracture with good bone quality. It might not be ideal for an 80-year-old due to potential complications from prolonged immobilization.

 

Option B. Bar and boot plaster: This non-surgical method also has limitations for elderly patients due to healing complications.

 

Option C. Intramedullary nailing: This surgical procedure uses nails to fix the fracture. While it can be an option, it might be risky for an 80-year-old's bone quality.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hemiarthroplasty is a surgical procedure where the damaged femoral head is replaced with an artificial joint, preserving the patient's own socket.
  • This offers a good balance between pain relief, mobility, and surgical complexity for elderly patients with this type of fracture.
  • The most appropriate management option for an 80-year-old patient with an intracapsular femoral neck fracture is Hemiarthroplasty.

questions.text: Select the correct sequence: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenylyl cyclase → cAMP → PKA

 

Explanation:

 

The sequence involves the activation of a G protein-coupled receptor pathway. When a hormone binds to its receptor, the associated heterotrimeric G protein undergoes a conformational change. This change leads to the exchange of GDP for GTP on the G protein's alpha subunit, causing it to dissociate from the beta and gamma subunits.

 

The activated GTP-bound alpha subunit then interacts with adenylyl cyclase, an enzyme located on the inner membrane of the cell. Adenylyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP). The newly formed cAMP acts as a secondary messenger that activates Protein Kinase A (PKA). PKA, in turn, phosphorylates various target proteins, leading to a cascade of cellular responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence in the G protein-coupled receptor pathway is: Adenylyl cyclase activates the conversion of ATP to cAMP, which then activates Protein Kinase A (PKA).

questions.text: A 23-year-old male came with complaints of orange hue over the body with hyperkeratotic perifollicular erythematous papules associated with scaling, which started near the face and slowly progressed to involve the entire body. Islands of sparing noted over the body. Palmoplantar keratoderma noted. Histology shows alternating orthokeratosis and parakeratosis. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris

 

Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP) is a rare skin disorder characterized by orange-red plaques, hyperkeratotic follicular papules, and scaling that typically starts on the face and progresses caudally (cephalocaudal spread) to involve the entire body.

 

A hallmark feature is the presence of “islands of sparing,” where patches of normal skin are surrounded by erythematous areas. The thickening of the skin over the palms and soles, known as palmoplantar keratoderma, is another distinguishing feature of PRP.

Histologically, PRP shows a distinctive pattern known as the "checkerboard" pattern, characterized by alternating areas of orthokeratosis (normal keratinization) and parakeratosis (abnormal keratinization).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycosis fungoides: Mycosis fungoides is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma that typically presents as patchy erythematous lesions, often resembling eczema or psoriasis, but it does not exhibit the cephalocaudal spread or islands of sparing characteristic of PRP. The histological findings also differ, with atypical lymphocytes being a hallmark of mycosis fungoides rather than the checkerboard pattern seen in PRP.

 

Option B. Follicular psoriasis: Psoriasis, including its follicular variant, usually presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered by silvery scales. While it may involve the palms and soles, the orange hue, islands of sparing, and cephalocaudal spread are not typical of psoriasis. Histologically, psoriasis shows uniform parakeratosis and elongation of the rete ridges rather than the alternating pattern seen in PRP.

 

Option D. Keratosis follicularis: Also known as Darier's disease, keratosis follicularis presents with greasy, warty papules, often in seborrheic areas. It lacks the distinctive orange hue, islands of sparing, and palmoplantar keratoderma seen in PRP. Histologically, Darier’s disease shows suprabasal acantholysis and dyskeratosis rather than the orthokeratosis and parakeratosis found in PRP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris is characterized by an orange-red hue with cephalocaudal spread, islands of sparing, palmoplantar keratoderma, and a histological "checkerboard" pattern of alternating orthokeratosis and parakeratosis

questions.text: Which of the following is a function of the marked layer? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium and water retention

 

The image shows the adrenal gland, which is divided into the cortex and the medulla. The cortex is further subdivided into three layers: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis.

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa: This is the outermost layer of the adrenal cortex and is responsible for the production of mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone. Aldosterone plays a key role in regulating sodium and water balance in the body, leading to sodium retention and water reabsorption in the kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluconeogenesis: Gluconeogenesis is primarily a function of the zona fasciculata, which secretes glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol) that promote glucose synthesis and metabolism.

 

Option C. Increased sex hormones: The zona reticularis is responsible for producing androgens, which are sex hormones. It does not contribute to sodium and water retention.

 

Option D. Immune cell interaction: While glucocorticoids from the zona fasciculata have some immunosuppressive effects, immune cell interaction is not a primary function of the marked layer, which is the zona glomerulosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex is responsible for sodium and water retention through the secretion of mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone.

questions.text: Wrist drop is typically a symptom of which type of nerve palsy? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a. Radial nerve palsy

 

Explanation:

 

Wrist drop is a classic sign of radial nerve palsy. The radial nerve supplies all the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers. When damaged, patients lose the ability to extend the wrist, leading to the characteristic "wrist drop" appearance. The radial nerve can be injured at various sites - in the axilla, spiral groove, or below the radial groove. Injury at the spiral groove, as seen in "Saturday night palsy," causes loss of extension at the wrist and fingers, resulting in wrist drop. The patient is unable to extend their hand at the wrist joint, and the hand hangs limply in a flexed position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior interosseous nerve injury: This is the deep branch of the radial nerve and would cause finger drop (inability to extend fingers) but typically maintains wrist extension, as it supplies the extensor digitorum but not the wrist extensors.

 

Option C. Ulnar nerve palsy: Causes claw hand deformity with hyperextension at metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at interphalangeal joints of the 4th and 5th digits. It does not cause wrist drop.

 

Option D. Carpal tunnel syndrome: Results from compression of the median nerve at the wrist, causing numbness and tingling in the thumb, index, middle fingers and lateral half of the ring finger, with weakness of thumb opposition and abduction. No wrist drop occurs.

 

 

Education Objective: 

 

Wrist drop is the pathognomonic sign of radial nerve injury, caused by paralysis of the wrist extensor muscles, particularly the extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis.

questions.text:
A diabetic, hypertensive, and post-MI patient on atorvastatin, metoprolol, and aspirin has lipid profile results of total cholesterol: 238 mg/dL, triglycerides: 125 mg/dL, HDL: 50 mg/dL, and LDL: 160 mg/dL. Which additional medications should be considered to optimize lipid management in this patient? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Bemepedoic acid
  2. Ezetimibe
  3. Gemfibrozil
  4. Evolocumab
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Explanation: 


The patient has elevated total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol with normal triglycerides and HDL. Therefore, drugs targeting cholesterol reduction would be most appropriate:

 

1. Bempedoic acid inhibits ATP citrate lyase, reducing cholesterol synthesis

 

2. Ezetimibe inhibits intestinal cholesterol absorption

 

4. Evolocumab (PCSK9 inhibitor) increases LDL receptor availability, enhancing LDL clearance All these mechanisms would help lower the elevated LDL and total cholesterol levels.

 

Other Option: 
 

3. Gemfibrozil is incorrect as fibrates primarily target high triglycerides, which are normal in this patient (125 mg/dL).

 

Educational Objective: 
 

Lipid-lowering medications based on the specific lipid abnormality: statins, PCSK9 inhibitors, ezetimibe, and bempedoic acid for elevated cholesterol/LDL; fibrates primarily for elevated triglycerides.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest marker for myocardial infarction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ischemia modified albumin

 

Ischemia-modified albumin (IMA) is considered one of the earliest markers for myocardial infarction (MI). It can be detected in the blood within minutes of ischemia and before any significant myocardial necrosis occurs.

 

The novelty of IMA lies in its ability to indicate ischemia even before traditional markers like CK-MB or Troponin I rise, making it particularly useful in the early diagnosis of MI. Its primary utility, however, is in its negative predictive value—if IMA levels are normal, it's more likely that the patient is not experiencing an MI.

 

Additionally,

 

Heart Fatty Acid Binding Protein (H-FABP), one more novel early marker is noted for its rapid response following myocardial injury. It can be detected early in the blood after the onset of a heart attack, making it a valuable tool for early diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CK-MB: CK-MB is a marker of myocardial injury that typically rises within 3-4 hours after the onset of infarction.

 

Option B. Lactate dehydrogenase 1 (LDH 1): LDH 1 is a late marker of myocardial infarction, typically rising 24-48 hours after the onset.

 

Note - LDH reacts with Triphenyl Tetrazole Chloride dye, which is used to visually differentiate between normal and infarcted cardiac tissue during diagnostic procedures. In the presence of this dye, normal cardiac tissue produces a big red color, while infarcted areas show a yellowish appearance. This color differentiation helps in identifying and assessing the extent of myocardial damage.

 

Option C. Cardiac Troponin I: Cardiac Troponins, especially Troponin I, are highly specific for myocardial injury and are the gold standard for diagnosing MI. However, they typically rise within 4-6 hours after the onset, making them less useful as the earliest marker compared to IMA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ischemia modified albumin (IMA) is an early biomarker for myocardial infarction, detectable shortly after ischemia begins, and is particularly valuable for its ability to rule out MI when levels are normal.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with decreased hearing in higher frequencies. It was noted that the basilar membrane was affected. Which of the following structures lie near the affected structure? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oval window

 

The affected structure in high-frequency hearing loss is the basal turn of the cochlea. Among the given options, the structure that lies near it is the oval window.

 

Movements of the stapes footplate, transmitted to the cochlear fluids, move the basilar membrane and set up shearing force between the tectorial membrane and the hair cells. The distortion of hair cells gives rise to cochlear microphonics, which trigger the nerve impulse. A sound wave, depending on its frequency, reaches maximum amplitude on a particular place on the basilar membrane and stimulates that segment (travelling wave theory of von Bekesy). Higher frequencies are represented in the basal turn of the cochlea and the progressively lower ones towards the apex.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modiolus: The central core of the cochlea around which the cochlear duct spirals. While important, it does not lie near the basal turn directly affected in high-frequency hearing loss.

 

Option B. Stria Vascularis: Located on the outer wall of the cochlear duct and is responsible for producing the endolymph. It plays a crucial role in maintaining the ionic composition of the endolymph but is not located near the oval window.

 

Option D. Helicotrema: The apex of the cochlea where the scala tympani and scala vestibuli meet, it is relevant for the transmission of lower frequency sounds, not high frequencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of high-frequency hearing loss, the basal turn of the cochlea near the oval window is typically involved. Understanding the anatomical proximity of the oval window to the basal turn helps in pinpointing the site of lesion and aids in specific diagnostic and therapeutic approaches aimed at the high-frequency hearing spectrum.

questions.text: Tandem radiotherapy is used in? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cervical cancer

 

Tandem radiotherapy, also known as intracavitary brachytherapy, is a specialized form of radiation treatment used primarily for cervical cancer. This technique involves the placement of radioactive sources directly into the cervix and uterus using a device called a tandem and ovoid applicator. The tandem is a metal rod that is inserted into the uterine cavity, and the ovoids are placed in the lateral fornices of the vagina. This allows for high doses of radiation to be delivered directly to the tumor while sparing the surrounding healthy tissues.

 

 

Intracavitary brachytherapy is often combined with external beam radiotherapy (EBRT) for the effective management of cervical cancer. This combined approach allows for better tumor control and increases the chances of preserving the function of surrounding organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ovarian cancer: This option is incorrect as radiotherapy is not commonly used for ovarian cancer. The primary treatment for ovarian cancer usually involves surgery followed by chemotherapy.

 

Option C. Endometrial cancer: This is incorrect because while radiotherapy can be used for endometrial cancer, the standard treatment is surgery followed by either chemotherapy or radiotherapy. Intracavitary brachytherapy is less commonly used compared to cervical cancer.

 

Option D. Choriocarcinoma: This is incorrect because the mainstay of treatment for choriocarcinoma is chemotherapy. Radiotherapy is not typically used for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem radiotherapy (intracavitary brachytherapy) is primarily used in the treatment of cervical cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following in IgA vasculitis warrants the use of corticosteroids? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GI bleeding

 

IgA vasculitis, also known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura, typically presents with symptoms such as arthritis, abdominal pain, and skin rash. These symptoms are often managed with supportive care and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). However, the use of corticosteroids is reserved for more severe manifestations of the disease.

 

GI bleeding: In cases where IgA vasculitis leads to gastrointestinal bleeding, corticosteroids are warranted. This is because GI bleeding indicates a severe form of the disease involving the gastrointestinal tract, which requires more aggressive treatment to reduce inflammation and prevent further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arthritis: Joint pain and swelling associated with IgA vasculitis are usually mild and managed with NSAIDs or supportive care. Corticosteroids are not typically indicated for arthritis alone in this context.

 

Option C. Abdominal pain: Abdominal pain in IgA vasculitis can often be managed with supportive care and NSAIDs. Corticosteroids are reserved for severe cases or when there is evidence of significant gastrointestinal involvement.

 

Option D. Skin rash: The characteristic purpuric rash of IgA vasculitis is usually self-limiting and does not require corticosteroids for treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are indicated in IgA vasculitis primarily for severe manifestations such as gastrointestinal bleeding, indicating more extensive disease involvement. Other manifestations, such as arthritis, abdominal pain, and skin rash, are generally self-limiting and respond well to supportive care. Corticosteroids are not typically required for these symptoms unless they are part of a more severe systemic involvement.

choices.text: Environmental enteropathy
Celiac disease
Whipple's disease

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. Duodenal biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

The clinical presentation and histopathological findings point to celiac disease.

 

Celiac disease is sometimes referred to as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. In genetically predisposed individuals, it is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by the consumption of gluten-containing cereals such as Barley, Rye, Oat & Wheat (BROW)

 

Almost all celiac disease patients have the class II HLADQ2 or HLA-DQ8 allele.

 

Histopathology: Increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis), crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy characterize the histopathology.

 

 

  • Prior to biopsy, noninvasive serologic tests are usually performed. The presence of IgA antibodies to tissue transglutaminase or IgA or IgG antibodies to deamidated gliadin is the most sensitive test. Anti-endomysial antibodies are more specific than other antibodies but less sensitive.
  • Clinical features: -
    • Malabsorption syndrome with chronic refractory anemia, chronic diarrhea, bloating, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss. A characteristic itchy, blistering skin lesion, dermatitis herpetiformis, can be present in as many as 10% of patients, and the incidence of lymphocytic gastritis and lymphocytic colitis is also increased.
    • Enteropathy associated T cell lymphoma
    • Small intestinal adenocarcinoma

 

Treatment – Gluten free diet results in symptomatic improvement for most patients, but a gluten-free diet may also reduce the risk of long-term complications including anemia, female infertility, osteoporosis, and cancer.

 

DAPSONE for dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Environmental enteropathy: Environmental enteropathy / tropical sprue is seen in tropical areas with poor sanitation. It is believed to be caused by one or more infectious agents that respond to antibiotics. Mucosa shows variable villous atrophy. Folic acid and B12 deficiency is common.

 

Option C. Whipple's disease: Whipple's disease is a multisystemic disease caused by T. whipplei. Small intestinal biopsy shows PAS-positive macrophages (see image below).

 

 

Option D. Chronic pancreatitis: Causes malabsorption due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Not associated with the specific histopathological features seen in celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is characterized by malabsorption, diarrhea, poor appetite, crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy, and increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes. It is diagnosed by serologic tests and confirmed with a duodenal biopsy. Treatment includes a strict gluten-free diet.

questions.text: The "Hanging Curtain Sign" is observed in which of the following conditions?  (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pityriasis Rosea.

 

  • The Hanging Curtain Sign is specifically associated with pityriasis rosea, particularly the herald patch. 
  • This sign is observed when stretching the skin along the long axis of the herald patch causes the scales to fold along the lines of stretch. 

 

 

  • This occurs because of the characteristic collarette scales found at the periphery of lesions in pityriasis rosea. 
  • These scales have their outer edge attached within the active margin of the lesion, while the inner edge remains free, allowing them to fold like a curtain when the skin is stretched.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psoriasis - This is incorrect. 

 

  • Psoriasis has characteristic silvery white scales that are loosely attached. 
  • When scraped, psoriasis demonstrates Auspitz sign (pinpoint bleeding) rather than the Hanging Curtain Sign. 
  • Psoriatic scales are uniformly distributed over the lesion rather than arranged in a collarette pattern.

 

Option B. Lichen Planus - This is incorrect. 

 

  • Lichen Planus is characterized by flat-topped, polygonal, violaceous papules with minimal scaling. 
  • The characteristic sign of lichen planus is Wickham's striae (whitish lacy pattern on the surface of the papules) rather than the Hanging Curtain Sign.

 

Option D. Hordeolum externum - This is incorrect. 

 

  • Hordeolum externum (external stye) is an acute infection of the sebaceous glands of Zeis or apocrine glands of Moll at the eyelid margin. 

 

 

  • It presents as a localized, painful, erythematous swelling and does not feature any scaling that would demonstrate the Hanging Curtain Sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hanging Curtain Sign is a characteristic feature of pityriasis rosea where stretching the herald patch causes the collarette scales to fold along the lines of stretch due to their unique attachment pattern with the outer edge attached and inner edge free.

questions.text: Graft rejection is seen maximum with which organ? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lungs

 

Explanation:

 

Among solid organ transplants, lungs have the highest risk of rejection, followed by the heart, kidneys, and liver. This is due to the lungs' constant exposure to the external environment and their rich supply of blood and lymphatic vessels, which increases the likelihood of the recipient's immune system encountering and reacting to foreign antigens from the transplanted lung tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart has the second-highest risk of rejection after lungs.

 

Option C. Intestine transplantation was not mentioned in the question stem or the explanation.

 

Option D. Kidney has a lower risk of rejection compared to lungs and heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of organ rejection risk from highest to lowest is:

 

  1. Lungs (maximum chances of rejection)
  2. Heart 
  3. Kidneys
  4. Liver

questions.text: What is the antigen present in the recombinant HPV vaccine?  (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) L1

 

Explanation:

 

The recombinant HPV vaccine primarily includes the L1 protein, which self-assembles into virus-like particles, providing the basis for immune recognition without causing the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E1 + E2: E1 and E2 are early viral proteins, not included in vaccines due to their role in viral replication.

 

Option B. E6 + E7: E6 and E7 are proteins involved in oncogenesis, not appropriate for vaccine development.

 

Option D. L2: L2 is also a capsid protein but not the primary antigen used in current HPV vaccines.

 

Educational objective:

 

The L1 protein of HPV forms the basis of the recombinant HPV vaccine, effectively stimulating an immune response by mimicking the virus structure.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a difficult prolonged labor where she says the baby was stuck for a long time; followed by cesarean section presents watery vaginal discharge on the 7th post operative day. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vesico-vaginal fistula

 

In cases of prolonged obstructed labor where the fetal head remains impacted in the pelvis for an extended period before cesarean section, there is a high risk of bladder necrosis. The prolonged pressure from the fetal head against the anterior vaginal wall and bladder can cause tissue ischemia. After cesarean delivery, this damaged tissue may break down, creating a fistulous connection between the bladder and vagina (vesico-vaginal fistula), resulting in continuous urinary leakage through the vagina. This typically presents as persistent watery vaginal discharge in the postoperative period.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Hydrorrhoea gravidarum: Incorrect as this condition refers to excessive watery discharge during pregnancy due to excessive secretion from endocervical glands, not relevant in a post-cesarean scenario.

 

Option C. Urinary retention: Incorrect because urinary retention would present with inability to pass urine and bladder distension, not watery vaginal discharge.

 

Option D. Rectovaginal fistula: Incorrect as this would present with passage of fecal matter through vagina, not watery discharge. While it can occur after difficult labor, it's less common than vesico-vaginal fistula.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Vesico-vaginal fistula is a known complication of prolonged obstructed labor
  • This presents as continuous watery discharge from the vagina between the 7th-10th day post delivery.
  • Prevention involves prolonged catheterization (2-3 weeks) in cases of obstructed labor to allow continuous bladder drainage and proper bladder healing.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are more susceptible to infections caused by catalase-positive organisms:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms. This condition arises from a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex in phagocytes, which is crucial for the production of reactive oxygen species used to kill ingested pathogens.

 

Key points about CGD:

 

  • Pathophysiology: In CGD, phagocytes (e.g., neutrophils and macrophages) are unable to produce reactive oxygen species due to a defective NADPH oxidase enzyme. This impairs the killing of certain bacteria and fungi.
  • Catalase-positive organisms: These organisms can neutralize hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), a reactive oxygen species that the host cells might produce. Catalase-positive bacteria include Staphylococcus aureus, Serratia marcescens, Aspergillus species, Nocardia, and Pseudomonas.
  • Recurrent Infections: Patients with CGD frequently suffer from recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly with catalase-positive organisms due to their inability to effectively kill these pathogens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyper IgM syndrome: This immunodeficiency disorder is characterized by elevated levels of IgM and low levels of other immunoglobulins due to defects in class-switch recombination. Patients are more prone to infections but not specifically with catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option C. Job syndrome (Hyper-IgE syndrome): Patients with Job syndrome have elevated levels of IgE and suffer from recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, pneumonia, and other infections. However, their susceptibility is not specifically related to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: This is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by defects in lysosomal trafficking, leading to impaired phagocytosis and recurrent bacterial infections. While patients are prone to infections, their susceptibility is not specifically to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme in phagocytes.

questions.text: Round pneumonia is most commonly associated with which of the following? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Streptococcal pneumonia 

 

Explanation: 

 

Round pneumonia is a distinct radiological pattern of pneumonia that appears as a round or oval opacity on chest imaging, mimicking a mass lesion. It is most commonly associated with Streptococcal pneumonia (Streptococcus pneumoniae infection). This presentation is particularly common in children under 8 years of age due to the lack of development of complete interlobular septae and pores of Kohn, which allows infection to spread more uniformly in a centrifugal pattern rather than respecting anatomical boundaries. Round pneumonia typically resolves completely with appropriate antibiotic therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kerosene oil aspiration - Incorrect. Kerosene aspiration typically causes chemical pneumonitis with bilateral infiltrates, often with a predominantly basal distribution. It does not present as round pneumonia but rather as diffuse or patchy infiltrates.

 

Option C. Lung cancer - Incorrect. While lung cancer can present as a round mass on imaging, this is not classified as round pneumonia. Round pneumonia is an infectious process that resolves with antibiotics, unlike malignant lesions.

 

Option D. Mendelson syndrome - Incorrect. This refers to chemical pneumonitis caused by aspiration of acidic gastric contents. It typically presents with bilateral infiltrates in dependent lung zones, not as a solitary round opacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Round pneumonia is a distinct radiological presentation most commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae infection in children, appearing as a well-defined round opacity that may mimic a tumor but resolves completely with appropriate antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old hypertensive male patient was taking hydrochlorothiazide. He developed fatigue and hypokalemia. Which of the following drug can be added to prevent loss of potassium in this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amiloride

 

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic, making it a suitable choice to add to the patient's regimen to prevent further potassium loss. This is particularly important in the context of the patient's fatigue and hypokalemia, likely side effects of hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic known to cause potassium loss. The other options listed would not be appropriate for addressing hypokalemia in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that actually increases the excretion of potassium, which would exacerbate hypokalemia rather than prevent it.

 

Option B. Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor diuretic. It is not typically used for preventing potassium loss and can also lead to hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Adenosine: Adenosine is primarily used as an antiarrhythmic agent for certain types of supraventricular tachycardias and is not used for managing electrolyte imbalances like hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic, works in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct of the nephron by inhibiting sodium channels. This action reduces potassium excretion, helping to prevent hypokalemia.

questions.text: A patient presented with clinical features of ataxia and incoordination. This is due to thrombosis of which artery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Superior cerebellar

 

  • Thrombosis of the superior cerebellar artery causes cerebellar lesion which presents with ataxia and incoordination.
  • The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) is a branch of the basilar artery and supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum, the roof nuclei, and parts of the midbrain.
  • When there is a thrombosis (formation of a blood clot) in the SCA, the blood supply to these areas is disrupted, which can cause various neurological symptoms such as ataxia, incoordination, and dizziness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior cerebral artery (PCA): It supplies blood to the occipital lobe, parts of the temporal lobe, and the inferomedial portion of the thalamus.

 

  • Thrombosis of the PCA can lead to:
    • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia (loss of half of the field of vision in both eyes)
    • Memory impairment (if it affects the hippocampus)
    • Alexia without agraphia (an inability to read without an inability to write) if the dominant hemisphere is involved.

 

Option B. Middle cerebral artery (MCA): It supplies blood to the majority of the outer convex brain surface, including the frontal, parietal, and superior temporal lobes.

 

  • Thrombosis of the MCA can lead to:
    • Contralateral hemiparesis and sensory loss (mainly of the face and upper limb)
    • If the dominant hemisphere (typically the left in right-handed individuals) is affected, expressive aphasia can occur.
    • If the non-dominant hemisphere is involved, spatial neglect might be observed.

 

Option C. Internal carotid artery (ICA): It does not give off any significant branches in its cervical or petrous portions. Its terminal branches in the brain are the MCA and ACA (anterior cerebral artery). Thrombosis of the ICA can compromise blood flow to both the ACA and MCA territories, leading to a combination of the symptoms associated with obstruction of those arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood supply of cerebellum:

 

  • Superior cerebellar artery
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery

 

Common symptoms of cerebellar lesions:

questions.text: How can total body fat be estimated accurately? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Hydrostatic Weighing

 

Explanation:


Hydrostatic weighing is considered the gold standard method for estimating total body fat. This technique measures body density by weighing a person both on land and while completely submerged in water. Since fat tissue is less dense than lean tissue, the overall body density can be used to calculate the percentage of body fat accurately. This method follows similar principles to those used in fluid volume estimation through displacement measurements.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Waist-Hip ratio - This measurement estimates fat distribution pattern (central versus peripheral) rather than total body fat percentage. It indicates risk for certain diseases but is not an accurate measure of total body fat content.
  • Option C. Body mass index - BMI is calculated from height and weight (kg/m²) and provides a general estimate of body composition. However, it doesn't distinguish between fat mass and lean mass, making it unreliable for accurate total body fat estimation, especially in athletes with high muscle mass.
  • Option D. Total body calcium - This measurement relates primarily to bone mineral density assessment, not body fat estimation. Total body calcium correlates with lean body mass rather than fat mass, making it unsuitable for total body fat determination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hydrostatic weighing provides the most accurate estimation of total body fat by determining body density through the displacement of water when submerged, allowing precise calculation of fat percentage.
